Comment: Many countries check to see if there’s some sort of accommodation even if on a “hike” vacation (pretty common in the US).   So even on American long trails (AT, PCT) requiring a 3 to 6+ month visa for most nights under a tent/tarp, .. it’s recommended the first hotel stay be the official address of the entire trip (note: overnight hikers will generally get a room every few days or so just to shower .. the “trail town” economies expect this unless a hiker is doing a speedy itinerary or going for a speed record .. aka “FKT”).  Actually had something similar happen when trying to enter Canada (I’d booked last minute); now I reserve low cost lodging w/a 24 hr front desk to start any international trip with the most expensive lodging latter (refundable).  Figure “day 1” I’ll be taking a shower/napping post flight anyways.

Comment: I agree that strict enforcement of this rule will hurt tourism. However, the US didn’t invent this practice.   The requirement of pre-arranged accommodations/lodging is required for tourists all around the world. If you visit Europe as a tourist, and you’re not a EU/EEA/CH citizen, you’re required to have pre-arranged lodging before entering or even before obtaining a tourist visa. Just look at Spain entry requirements.   The only reason European students have been entering the US without pre-booking hostels is because they’ve had privileged passports. Generally, if you come from a rich country, immigration police will be chill. However, if a Chilean were to go to Spain, that person would have to demonstrate their accommodation itinerary and proof of having sufficient cash just to enter.   Even as an American, I’ve been asked where I’m staying, requiring the exact address, when visiting South America. It is pretty damn standard and complaining about it is a little bit entitled.  I have never visited another country without having my lodging pre-arranged, be it friend’s place, hotel, AirBnb, etc. Heck, when I was a student in 2014 and went to Europe, staying in the stingiest hostels in Paris and Brussels, I pre-booked them to save money.  To reiterate, I’m not justifying the jailing and mistreatment of these girls. That is unacceptable. All I’m saying is that the denial of entry to a country for not arranging accommodations ahead of time is common.
Author: CLUSSaitua

Comment: I've been asked exactly once. It's a common official requirement, but nobody really bothers with asking for proof of travel arrangements unless they're trying to give you a hard time or think you plan to overstay or some such.
Author: account312

Comment: I've not been asked about where I was staying in country, but I have been asked about my return flight information in a very routine manner. "Ah, I see here you're staying until the 16th?" Yes. "And are you returning to America or headed somewhere else on your trip?"   It never felt like I was being "questioned by agents of the state" but it was definitely a routine part of just the dozen or so questions you get asked while they process you through customs and stamp the forms. The only time I had anything go weird was also when I realized those routine questions were not just idle small talk with the agent at the gate, because I DIDN'T have a return flight booked and was instead leaving the country by boat so they asked for the boat's information, captain's name, itinerary, etc.   Even then, it was still handled quickly and efficiently once we knew what to put on the forms, but customs agents in most tourism destinations see dozens or hundreds of people per day so they make the questions and answer sections so smooth you don't even notice that they're extracting this information from you. It's just something they type into the computer to put on the forms, they stamp your passport and/or entry visa, and you're on your way to baggage claim.
Author: theCaitiff

Comment: In 2017 when I traveled to Italy, I was asked if I had reservations, but I had planned ahead and had them printed out. I think if I wouldn't have had any info with me perhaps they would have asked an additional question or two. When my wife went up after me, they were like "Are you with him?" and then were like "Enjoy your stay..."
Author: Alieges
